title: Danny Banks: ‚ÄúAn Introduction to Multi-Platform Design Systems‚Äù ‚Äî¬†Clarity 2020
description:
You already have amazing design systems with battle-tested components, thorough documentation, and a frictionless developer experience - there's just one small problem: it's web-only. Let's expand our design systems thinking to create a cohesive multi-platform experience that works for customers and creators. In this talk we will explore the environments, ergonomics, and economics of building design systems on multiple platforms.

Presented by Danny Banks at Clarity 2020, on September 4th, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Alison Rand: ‚ÄúMutualism‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
Design Systems and Design Operations are often conflated, with good reason. The two are inextricably tied, each building off a mutually beneficial holistic system with the whole greater than the sum of its parts. The symbiotic relationship enables higher-performing teams, a more efficient workflow, and allows companies to better understand design to drive business impact, and directly impact the customer experience.

Presented by Alison Rand at Clarity 2020, on September 4th, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Brittney Ball: ‚ÄúCreating Inclusive Content: Why it Matters‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
Have you ever attempted to learn something new only to find that most of the content was either too hard to follow/understand and or left you more confused than when you first started, too technical, or doesn‚Äôt hold your attention? 

This talk will get into why inclusive content is important, how to make sure the content creating is inclusive, and how creators, learners, and companies can all benefit from inclusive content.

Presented by Brittney Ball at Clarity 2020, on September 4th, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Farai Madzima: ‚ÄúDesigning Systems. Designing Teams.‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
The language we use to describe effective design systems seems so similar to the language we use to describe how effective teams work.

‚ÄúAuthentic and genuine principles‚Äù, ‚Äúa shared language‚Äù, ‚Äúclear channels of communication‚Äù, ‚Äúclear governance structures‚Äù, ‚Äúfrequent checkups‚Äù.

See what I mean? Read any decent article or book on effective design systems or effective teams and these üëÜüèæ concepts are gonna come up. Why? Because a team is also a system. It‚Äôs just that we don‚Äôt think of it that way, because its ‚Äúpeople stuff‚Äù. So we avoid it. Because ‚Äúpeople stuff‚Äù is ‚Äúhard‚Äù.

I‚Äôd like to convince you otherwise. In this talk I‚Äôll share practical tips on how any team can become more effective when it thinks of itself as a system. Not only that, I‚Äôll show how to do this using some of the core principles and techniques we already know, love, and use to build effective design systems.

You don‚Äôt have to be a lead or a manager to make your team more inclusive and effective. You just need to care about design, systems, and people. That‚Äôs why you‚Äôre here right?

Presented by Farai Madzima at Clarity 2020, on September 4th, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Sam Kapila: ‚ÄúDesigning for Happiness‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
How do you design for happiness? How do you design for an app where the most important action happens outside of the app? We'll dive into how different parts of a mobile design system started coming together in an MVP and the way happiness became part of collaboration. 

Presented by Sam Kapila at Clarity 2020, on September 3rd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Una Kravetz: ‚ÄúCalculating Color: Dynamic Theming with CSS Variables‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
Did you know that you can build custom dynamic color themes without the use of JavaScript or a CSS preprocessor!? With the magic of CSS Custom Properties, HSL colors, and some calc() fun, you too can create custom theming with no dependencies. In this talk, Una will show you how.

Presented by Una Kravets at Clarity 2020, on September 3rd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Asia Hoe: ‚ÄúThe Systems of Design‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
Design, and in turn, Design Systems, are innately political. When done well, design makes products and services more accessible, inclusive, and equitable. But what about the systems that enable and teach us the expression of design? Looking at everything from the software and hardware we use, to the internet service providers that enable us to enjoy cloud based software, this talk reveals the inequity in the systems that power design, and what we can do about it to enable a brighter, more diverse, and more inclusive future.

Presented by Asia Hoe at Clarity 2020, on September 3rd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Alex Skougarevskaya: ‚ÄùDesign Systems as Service: Keeping your Customers Happy‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
You‚Äôve got a design system, now what? At Atlassian we‚Äôve evolved what it means to create, adopt, and maintain a design system over the past 5 years, from a product for products, to a service for people. In this talk, I'll dig deep into who the consumers of our systems are, and some of the things we've done (some that worked, others that didn't) to meet their needs.

Presented by Alex Skougarevskaya at Clarity 2020, on September 2nd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Allison Shaw: ‚ÄúAccessibility Beyond Color Contrast‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
You've heard about accessibility, and people keep talking about making products more inclusive. But what does that mean? Why does it matter? And how do you do it? Can design systems help? In this talk, we‚Äôll go beyond simple color contrast to understand foundational accessibility and inclusion principles. You‚Äôll leave with concrete steps you can take to make your products more accessible and inclusive without dedicated resources.

Presented by Alison Shaw at Clarity 2020, on September 2nd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Natalya & Tim Shelburne: ‚ÄúDesign Systems, or: How I learned to stop fighting and love the team‚Äù
description:
Why do we still hear about the gap between design and engineering, given that design systems exist? Because, like any other partnership, design systems take work. Natalya (designer!) and Tim (engineer...) have worked together for over a decade, and are still married!

This talk cuts through the noise to honestly and practically discuss working across disciplines, respecting the talents of your teammates, and enabling everyone to contribute to a common goal.

Presented by Nataya & Tim Shelburne at Clarity 2020, on September 3rd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Jina Anne: ‚ÄúThe Design Systems Spiral‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
In many tutorials about design systems, the process to begin shows a linear, step-by-step recipe ‚Äî planning and research, then designing, then developing, then distributing, and finally, then maintaining. But does it ever really work that way?

Jina will discuss her thoughts on how we talk about design systems, and reconciling that with the real-world realities of what we really face when we do this work.

Presented by Jina Anne at Clarity 2020, on September 2nd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Ben Colar: ‚ÄúThe Importance of Perspective‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2020
description:
While in the weeds of a design project, it‚Äôs easy to lose track of an overall objective. Especially if you‚Äôre only responsible for a small piece of that objective. But design should always come from a perspective. Usually that perspective is developed at the origin of the brand. In this session, Ben will go through the process of developing a brand perspective, and how that can affect design decisions down the road.

Presented by Ben Colar at Clarity 2020, on September 2nd, 2020. Ends with an interview with Dan Mall.

title: Clarity 2020 Recap
description:
NOTE: This video does not have any vocal audio, so it does not have captioning.

Clarity is a design systems conference focused on how we work together. We provide tools and standards to scale across an increasing number of devices, platforms, and products. But real success comes when people align around a shared vision and language. Diverse perspectives for design, development, and product unite so more people can be a part of the conversation. At Clarity, we elevate our skills through multi-faceted inclusion, empathy, technology, creativity, and collaboration.

https://www.clarityconf.com

title: 2020 Year in Review: A Design Systems Community Panel (DSCC Toronto)
description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Toronto
on YouTube
on December 2, 2020

Design Systems Community Chapter (DSCC) Toronto is proud to host an end-of-year live panel on December 2, 2020. We‚Äôre bringing together industry leaders to discuss the impact of COVID-19 to our day-to-day, evolved collaboration with our design system peers, and how the new normal may shape industries in the future.

Meet the panelists:
--
Ash Guillaume, Systems Designer at GitHub

Ash is currently a systems designer at GitHub where he maintains the Figma resources for Primer, GitHub's design system. In addition to diving deep into the layers of components, Ash creates tools and resources for his team to help them work smarter, faster, and happier. Prior to GitHub Ash was the lead marketing designer at Postman (the API tool) where he helped to shape the brand and marketing materials.
Outside of design systems, Ash can be found riding his bike(s) near the beach or spending time with his partner and their dog.

https://twitter.com/itmeashygee

--
Ethelia Lung, Interaction Designer at YouTube

Ethelia‚Äôs a transplant to California from Hong Kong. Primarily focused in the digital space, she‚Äôs detail-oriented, gently opinionated, and a bit of a perfectionist. Ethelia currently works as an Interaction Designer at YouTube.

https://twitter.com/theilsanne

--
Sara Hill, Senior Product Designer at Shopify

I‚Äôm an Ottawa based designer working on design systems at Shopify. An interesting fact about me is one of my first jobs was illustrating t-shirt designs for Harley Davidson... lots of flames and chrome.

https://twitter.com/sarahill22

--
Stephen McGuinness, Design Systems Lead, Growth Marketing at GitLab

Hello everyone! I'm Stephen, design system lead at GitLab! I am Irish living in Vancouver. I have previously worked with Lucy and Enrico at Telus, and more recently I worked at Lululemon on their E-Commerce design system. An interesting fact about me, I have 2 Harley Davidsons and I have met Mike Tyson!

https://twitter.com/gintonious

üëáüèøüëáüèæüëáüèΩüëáüèºüëáüèª

Topics we will discuss include:
- How has the pandemic affected your Design System?
- How has collaboration changed at your workplace?
- What are your teams working on that‚Äôs new and exciting?
- Shifts in industry and design systems thinking, and looking ahead

Agenda

title: Laying Foundations for Quality (DSCC Toronto)
description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Toronto
on YouTube
on September 16, 2020

--
2:32 Introduction
9:00 Talk #1: Modern patterns in modular software design by Ahmad Nassri
37:16 Talk #1 Questions and Answers
48:46 Talk #2: The evolution of Shopify‚Äôs color system by Kaelig Deloumeau-Prigent
1:27:53 Talk #2: Questions and Answers
1:39:42 Closing remarks
--

Who should attend?
Anyone and everyone who is interested in learning about design systems is welcome. This event does not require background knowledge.

--
Talk #1: Modern patterns in modular software design
Ahmad Nassri, Fractional CTO, Answerable & hashtagpaid

Modular architecture patterns have been around for a long time, longer than some of us have even been alive! The pipe-dream to create a fully modular software system is still alive and strong, so what have we learned over the years and across different practices? And how do teams today adopt a modern view to an age-old problem?

About Ahmad
Ahmad is a software developer and advocate of all things open-source. A startup advisor and mentor to entrepreneurs & developers, he founded Tech Masters ‚Äî a developer community of over 10,000+ members engaging in discussions on technology, careers, and learning. He is currently a Fractional CTO supporting multiple startups. Prior to his current role, he was CTO of npm, chief architect for TELUS Digital, and VP of Engineering at Kong. 
https://ahmadnassri.com/

--
Talk #2: The evolution of Shopify‚Äôs color system
By Kaelig Deloumeau-Prigent, UX Developer, Shopify

In this talk, Kaelig covers a case study in how Shopify uses design tokens as the technical foundations of its color system, scaling it to multiple platforms, and with accessible theming in mind.

About Kaelig
Kaelig is a UX developer on the Polaris design system team at Shopify. In the past, he worked on a variety of design systems for companies such as Salesforce, the Guardian, the BBC, and the Financial Times. In 2016, he started talking about Design Systems Ops, a set of principles freely inspired from the DevOps movement, applied to front-end and design systems.
https://www.deloumeau.fr/

title: Anil Dash: ‚ÄúDesigning for the Impossible‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Closing Keynote.

Most of the tech industry treats goals like inclusion, ethics and empathy as impossible. Here's how to get it done anyway.

NOTE: This talk did not have slides.

Presented by Anil Dash at Clarity 2019, on August 21st, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Tatiana Mac: ‚ÄúSystem of Systems‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Design systems create an umbrella to to define the future of our design work. But design systems are not the biggest umbrella, so to speak‚Äîthey exist under broader social, political, and infrastructural systems that affect the parameters, limitations, and variables of our system.

Investigating design systems across many verticals, we'll look to see how design systems are impacted by the systems they live within. And beyond the verticals, we'll look to see how broader systems of power and oppression influence the design systems, and ultimately, the users who use the products defined by them.

We'll look to see how to assess where our design systems live in broader ecosystems, the challenges inherent, and how to lean into the good, and resist the bad, to ensure we're serving all humans in an equitable and ethical way, maintaining safety and trust.

Presented by Tatiana Mac at Clarity 2019, on August 21st, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Harry Roberts: ‚ÄúMore Than You Ever Wanted to Know About Resource Hints‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Resource Hints are a great way for developers to make their web pages faster by allowing us to be a little bit smarter than the browser. Although not a new specification‚Äîthey‚Äôve been around in some form or another for years!‚Äîare we truly getting the most out of them? And do we understand them thoroughly enough to use them most effectively? Heck, do we even know what a ‚ÄòResource Hint‚Äô is?! Well, by the end of this talk, we‚Äôll all be experts.

Let‚Äôs take a look at all of the different Resource Hints we have available to us, real-world examples of how best to use them, and learn about some of the more obscure intricacies and gotchas that we need to be aware of if we want to really get the best out of them (and to make sure that we really are being smarter than the browser).

Presented by Harry Roberts at Clarity 2019, on August 21st, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Stephanie Rewis & Brandon Ferrua: ‚ÄúDesigning Standard Systems‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Is your Design System mature and hard to maintain? In this talk we‚Äôll discuss how web components can help us manage the overhead of a design system ‚Äî freeing us from the dependencies we have become so accustomed to having. Come with us as we move into a leaner world and build on more primitive/fundamentals of the standardized web.

Presented by Stephanie Rewis & Brandon Ferrua at Clarity 2019, on August 21st, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Dan Eden: ‚ÄúWhere We Can Go‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Today‚Äôs design and engineering tools are poorly suited for creating or working within design systems. What would our tools look like if they treated design systems as the building material, rather than an abstract thing we gesture towards?

Presented by Dan Eden at Clarity 2019, on August 21st, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Mina Markham: ‚ÄúFull-Featured Art Direction for the Web‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Now that we have the tools to superpower our layouts, we can start to reimagine how we approach art direction and design on the web. By taking advantage of technologies, some new and some overlooked, we can create a progressively-enhanced design that‚Äôs powered by feature queries; one that‚Äôs localized for an increasingly global audience. In this talk drawn from her work for Slack and other properties, Mina walks through her process for enhancing design and shows how little changes lead to big design payoffs.

Presented by Mina Markham at Clarity 2019, on August 21st, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Ethan Marcotte: ‚ÄúThe World-Wide Work‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
These days, it‚Äôs easy to feel overwhelmed. The tech industry is facing a veritable raft of ethical, moral, and political crises. Automation and industrialization are reshaping our world. And sitting in the middle of all that? You and me. We‚Äôre digital designers, we‚Äôre developers, we‚Äôre product owners. But each day, our work is changing ‚Äî more quickly than it ever has before.

Here‚Äôs the question we have to ask ourselves: what do we want that change to be? In this talk, we‚Äôll look at some of the challenges facing our industry, and ask ourselves: what kind of work do we want to do?

Presented by Ethan Marcotte at Clarity 2019, on August 20th, 2019.

title: Teresa Aguilera & Nicole Torgersen: ‚ÄúPartnership & Trust to Fuel Growth‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
A journey through our collaboration model within Gap inc that helped build Stitch Design System.

Presented by Teresa Aguilera & Nicole Torgersen at Clarity 2019, on August 20th, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Val Head: ‚ÄùPutting Your Brand in Motion‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
When your type and color say one thing, but your use of animation says another, things can get confusing. Defining how your brand should express itself in motion gives you the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù of your UI animation efforts, and establishes a concrete way to ensure your UI animations share a common thread both with each other, and with the rest of your design efforts.

In this session, Val will show you how to harness the design details of UI animation to reinforce your intended design messaging. By using every tool at our disposal, we can create more expressive products that feel cohesive across all of today's diverse contexts.

Presented by Marcy Sutton at Clarity 2019, on August 20th, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Marcy Sutton: ‚ÄùGarbage Pail Components‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Oh, the horror! Hot garbage has taken over the web. Carousel Carol, Type-Ahead Tommy, Shallow Dom, Wastin' JSON...the gang's all here. We'll turn the "bad accessibility" dial up to 11 in order to feel the pain that users with disabilities experience on a regular basis. Some of the patterns in this talk will be directly inspired from real life instances‚Äìbecause we can't even make this stuff up. By facing our miserable fears and burning everything to the ground, we'll be reborn and better equipped to create truly successful user interfaces.

Presented by Marcy Sutton at Clarity 2019, on August 20th, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Rune Madsen & Martin Bravo: ‚ÄùCode is a Material‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Talk previously called "Graphic Design Systems".

In this talk, design duo Rune Madsen and Martin Bravo will talk about their work in the intersection of graphic design and programming languages. The talk will focus on key concepts from Madsen‚Äôs book Programming Design Systems and how these same ideas influence their work when developing design systems for digital products, dynamic identities, or custom design tools.

Presented by Rune Madsen & Martin Bravo at Clarity 2019, on August 20th, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: Denise Jacobs: ‚ÄùCo-Create: Creating Better Together‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2019
description:
Despite the prevalent mythology of the lone creative genius, many of the most innovative contributions spring from the creative chemistry of a group and the blending of everyone‚Äôs ideas and concepts. How can we best leverage this collective wisdom to generate creative synergy and co-create? Let‚Äôs look at the process of recognizing and removing our personal creative blocks, connecting and communicating with others, combining ideas using play, and constructing a collaborative environment to discover effective methods for tapping into a group‚Äôs creative brilliance. Through these steps, you‚Äôll learn to capitalize on the super-linearity of creativity to embrace and leverage diversity to create better together.

Presented by Denise Jacobs at Clarity 2019, on August 20th, 2019. Ends with an interview with Brad Frost.

title: John Maeda: ‚ÄùInclusive Design‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
Closing Keynote with Q&A panel

Presented by John Maeda at Clarity 2018, on December 12th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis, joined by Alexis Lloyd and Alison Rand.

title: Yasmine Evjen & Michelle Alvarez: ‚ÄùMaterial Theming: Building an Expressive Design ‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
How Google made Material more expressive, giving teams the ability to customize Material Design to better reflect their product‚Äôs brand.

Presented by Yasmine Evjen & Michelle Alvarez at Clarity 2018, on December 12th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis.

title: Dan Mall: ‚ÄùPutting the ‚ÄúDesign‚Äù in Design Systems‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
Let‚Äôs face it: design systems are tools to largely help developers to create well-designed products. And that‚Äôs great! Consistency, headstarts, and shared standards are good for everyone. But where does that leave designers? How do we exercise the advantages of gorgeous art direction and intuitive interaction design? Why does it feel like the job we‚Äôve been successfully doing for years is quickly fading away? Dan Mall has been coaching and working with in-house teams on their design systems for a few years. In this talk, he‚Äôll share what he‚Äôs learned about each team member‚Äôs role, where to be efficient vs. where to be experimental, and how we can all better collaborate to benefit from everyone‚Äôs knowledge and skills.



Presented by Dan Mall at Clarity 2018, on December 12th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis.

title: Selling & scaling design systems (DSCC Czechia)
description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Czechia
on July 1, 2020

--
0:00 Introduction
5:05 Talk #1: "Building consistency in the world of autonomous teams" by Ond≈ôej Havl√≠ƒçek
31:26 Talk #2: "How we solve inconsistencies in patterns to improve Quadient Design System" by Richard Grof, UX designer at Quadient
51:59 Questions and Answers
1:09:15 Outro
---

Talk #1: "Building consistency in the world of autonomous teams" by Ond≈ôej Havl√≠ƒçek,
This talk is about how Quadient is dealing with the challenges on their ‚Äûroad to a design system‚Äú. A story about the experience with implementing a design system in a large software company whose culture has always been about the great autonomy of the software development teams. It is about building a structure without a budget and without a dedicated team. Can there be some advantages to it?

About Ond≈ôej:
Ond≈ôej fell in love with UX design in 2008. Since 2012 I have been in charge of the UX & Graphics team at GMC Software Technology, later renamed to Quadient. Our software helps companies who need to communicate with their clients. He feels very strongly about the idea of consistency as part of great user experience. They started with a style guide, then a UI pattern library, and finally, they're working on a design system now.

---

Talk #2: "How we solve inconsistencies in patterns to improve Quadient Design System" by Richard Grof, UX designer at Quadient
This talk will focus on two main areas:
- Case study: Removing inconsistencies from UI patterns across the application.
- Identifying opportunities for continuous improvements of the design system.

About Richard:
Richard work as a UX designer at Quadient. He has a passion for designing for user-friendly and accessible interfaces with meaningful interactions and reusability in mind.
Sponsors:
Special thanks to productboard and Kiwi.com for sponsoring this meetup.

---

title: Designing for Development & Communicating Design Systems (DSCC Berlin)
description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Czechia
on July 15, 2020

--
4:56 Introduction
11:28 Talk 1: Communicating design systems - Viktoriia Leontieva (Senior product designer at Github)

Talk 1: Communicating design systems - Viktoriia Leontieva (Senior product designer at Github)

On the surface, a design system is a collection of design tokens: color, layout, typography, iconography, etc. but behind each is a series of decisions that shape its current form. The result is a reflection of your team‚Äôs ability to arrive at a simple, single answer in conversations with maintainers and users. This talk is informed by a series of interviews with system designers to get to the bottom of why, and how, communicating your design system is the key to its success.

Talk 2: Designing for Development, building a Design System at Brainly - Patrycja Rozmus (Design system lead at Brainly)

In this talk, Patrycja will introduce the history of the design system and design processes at Brainly, explain the genesis of their homemade design system tooling that became popular worldwide - Html-Sketchapp. She will also dive into the struggles connected to selling design systems to business and present some takeaways that might be useful for other teams.

--

description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Dublin
on YouTube
on June 16, 2020

Sponsored by:
Special thanks to NearForm for sponsoring this meetup.

Who should attend?
Anyone and everyone who is interested in learning about design systems are welcome. This event does not require background knowledge.

--
Talk #1: "Communication between designers and developers, the infinite loop." by James Malone, Design Director at NearForm

Design systems include documentation for many things like colours, content and principals. Collaboration and internal communication however are often not part of this process, but they should be. Drawing on personal experience, James will discuss how to plan and think about collaboration from the start.

About James
James Malone is the design director at NearForm with over two decades of design experience. James has worked in a multitude of industries managing small and large design teams. James is passionate about Design Operations, improving efficiency through collaboration, and dismantling the fabled gap between design and development.

--
Talk #2: "Breaking down silos, automation, workflows, tools and humans." by Stuart Giles, Senior Product Designer at NearForm

Design systems are built to meet the bespoke requirements of a company, team or organisation. Each one is different and unique. In a similar way, the teams that use these systems are unique and different too. Stuart looks at how to break down silos and create tools, workflows and processes that are customised to the unique users who use them.

About Stuart
Stuart is a Senior Product Designer at NearForm where he works with large household brands to implement, scale and automate design systems. As a lead product designer he defines the experience of digital products through research, design, and development phases. Stuart is as happy in Sketch as he is at a command line and jumps between the two seamlessly.

title: Adekunle Oduye: ‚ÄùThe Three P‚Äôs of a Design System‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
Is there a way we can build a design system that give engineers production ready UI components but also assist designers in crafting front-end prototypes? Learn about the three Ps and how it can help achieve these goals.

Presented by Adekunle Oduye at Clarity 2018, on December 11th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis.

title: Sarah Drasner: ‚ÄúComposable Animation‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
Design Systems have changed the way that developers and designers collaborate on fonts, colors, UI structure, forms and the like. So why does it feel like animation in a design system always falls short? The animation section usually lays dormant aside from a "fade", or we craft one-offs for a perfect experience, but each perfect experience becomes less perfect because they don't share the same language. In this talk, we'll break down exactly how to build animations so that they're composable, extendable, and can be used for a multitude of purchases, and still maintain cohesion. We'll talk about how animation in specific requires teams to work together because it's an intersection of design and development: it's harder to throw over a wall. We'll break down exactly how to make it all fit together, for the most seamless collaboration between you and your team.

Presented by Sarah Drasner at Clarity 2018, on December 11th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis.

title: Yesenia Perez Cruz: ‚ÄúScenario-Driven Design Systems‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
Unified design systems are essential to building, maintaining, and evolving our sites and products. By empowering disparate teams via a common visual and UX language, they help us create cohesive user experiences. But creating a unified system that scales to serve a variety of content and use cases can be challenging. Sharing insights from her experience creating a unified design system for eight media brands with eight distinct editorial strategies, Yesenia will show how to approach a design system via a user-centered lens. Learn how being scenario-driven helps you design a scalable system that responds flexibly to specific contexts.

Presented by Yesenia Perez-Cruz at Clarity 2018, on December 11th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis.

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Inayaili Le√≥n
description: I held an AMA with Cap Watkins over Zoom at 9am PDT May 15, 2020.

title: Kim Williams: ‚ÄúStart with Your Brand Purpose‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
Creating cohesive brand patterns and components that make your product experience distinctive.

Presented by Kim Williams at Clarity 2018, on December 11th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis

title: Sharon Steed: ‚ÄúCreating Cultures of Empathy‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2018
description:
The same general trajectory: a decent idea executed flawlessly by a cohesive team of hard workers. No matter the project, everything can be achieved following this general guideline. But the exact thing that can create global companies, solve impossible problems and bring ideas to life is also the same reason why so many companies fail. That *thing* is us. People. And when we‚Äôre at our best, there isn‚Äôt anything we can't do. So how do we optimize collaboration? How do we work better together even if we don‚Äôt see eye-to-eye with everyone on our teams? And how do we create a culture of empathy when all we can see about everyone around us is our differences?

This talk will explore empathy in an unusual way: from the perspective of a stutterer. We‚Äôll examine what empathy truly is (and is not) and reveal the specific actions individuals must engage in daily to create a culture of empathy on their team.

Presented by Sharon Steed at Clarity 2018, on December 11th, 2018. Ends with an interview with Nathan Curtis

title: Henri Helvetica: ‚ÄúPerformance by Design‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Design systems have conceptually been very well documented and discussed, yielding fantastic UX results.

Web engineers have painstakingly audited, researched, and crunched numbers in order to also provide fantastic UX.

Sound familiar?

Performance By Design will explore how Design systems and web performance work in concert to achieve same first class UX result.

title: Isha Kasliwal: ‚ÄúWhat Happens Next? Everything That Comes After Setting Up Your Desi‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
So you‚Äôve gotten buy-in, you‚Äôve made an inventory of designs and components, and you‚Äôve set up your team‚Äôs first design system. What happens next? This talk will explore maintaining a design system, as well as new challenges that arise once your design system matures. Topics that this talk will cover will include: documentation, adoption, support, tooling, and architecture.

Presented by Isha Kasliwal at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Josh Silverman: ‚ÄúThe People Layer‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
The People Layer is the deepest, most complex layer of any organization. It‚Äôs a layer of interaction that persists beyond changes in aesthetics, technologies, devices, systems, tools, and trends. Everyone is involved, and everyone can solve for it.

Presented by Josh Silverman at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Content in Design Systems (DSCC Toronto)
description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Toronto
on YouTube
on May 6, 2020

Talk #1: How Content Graduated From Voice Guidelines to Patterns and Systems
Ryan Bigge, Senior Content Strategist , Shopify

We started with voice and tone guides for copywriters. Then content design patterns emerged. Today, many design systems have embedded content guidelines for each component. Drawing on personal experience, Ryan will discuss how his work as a product content strategist has been shaped by Polaris, Shopify‚Äôs design system.

About Ryan
Ryan Bigge is a senior content strategist on Shopify‚Äôs Financial Services team. He spent a decade as a freelance print journalist before going digital. Ryan has talked about about boring UX in Pittsburgh (Abstractions 2019) and improving personalized recommendations in Chicago (IA Summit 2018).

--
Talk #2: Content for Design Systems: Measuring Success
Jacqui Clydesdale, UX Writer and Content Strategist

‚ÄúWhat does success look like?‚Äù is something we often ask of content, and the answer can be pretty straightforward for a marketing email or an onboarding flow. But what makes for a good metric for the content in a design system? Drawing on her experience in UX and adult language learning, Jacqui will explore who the users of a design system are, what they need from it, and how writers can develop, test and iterate content to meet everyone‚Äôs needs.

About Jacqui
Jacqui Clydesdale is a UX writer and content strategist in Toronto. She has a background in linguistics, English literature and second language teaching, so it‚Äôs pretty clear that she loves words. Over the past eight years, she‚Äôs developed digital content for Kobo, Canadian Tire, Fast Retailing (Uniqlo), Dick‚Äôs Sporting Goods, Shaw, and several startups. She‚Äôs agnostic when it comes to the Oxford comma.

--

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Miriam Suzanne
description:
I held an AMA with Miriam Suzanne over Zoom at 9am PDT May 5, 2020.

Note: When I did the call Miriam's audio seemed equal with mine ‚Äî but for some reason on the recording, my voice is much louder than hers. Sorry about that!

title: Diana Mounter: ‚ÄúThe Interaction of Color Systems‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Color is the most relative medium in art. This fact makes working with color in design systems particularly challenging. Few people seem to want to claim to be an expert in color‚Äîperhaps because there‚Äôs an immensely deep amount to learn, or perhaps it‚Äôs because color is one of those things we hate to get wrong. Whatever the reason, color remains a contentious but often critical part of design.

I‚Äôll be sharing my journey into color, from the technical challenges to how people respond to it. We‚Äôll take a look at the efforts required in updating large scale web applications like GitHub, testing the interaction of color with other parts of a design system, creating color naming conventions, color contrast, and color system use outside of the product UI.

Presented by Diana Mounter at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Cap Watkins: ‚ÄúHow to VP‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
A very common question I get, whether at a conference, on a panel or even from people I work with at BuzzFeed, is what my day-to-day work is like as a VP of Design. Since no one week or day is exactly the same, I've historically had trouble answering this question. No more!

In this talk, I‚Äôll detail a full, actual week of being a VP of Design at BuzzFeed, along with some lessons I‚Äôve learned in my role that I have found to apply broadly to leaders across all levels of an organization.

Presented by Cap Watkins at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Mina Markham: ‚ÄúDoing it Wrong‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Just as there‚Äôs no one way to make a website, there is no one way to make a design system. While there are several ‚Äúbest practices‚Äù that have emerged, there is no one-size-fits-all solution for creating a design system. And sometimes, the best solution means going against industry standards.

In this talk, Mina will discuss her experiences building systems at two highly visible, and vastly different, organizations: Hillary for America and Slack. She‚Äôll tell you all the things and all the ways she got it wrong, while somehow making it work.

Presented by Mina Markham at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Tatiana Mac
description: I held an AMA with Tatiana Mac over Zoom at 9am PDT May 1, 2020.

title: Elyse Holladay: ‚ÄúA Working Theory of Components‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Throughout history, our tools have affected how we understand the world. In our young industry, our tools, needs, and processes are constantly changing. We build sites and frameworks and components with the tools we have at hand. As we do, we discover problems, invent solutions, and then invent new tools.

Design Systems are our current model of making sense of the intersection of front-end code and design. With the tools we have today, what is our working model of a component? How do we define them, create them, and ensure they work at scale? In this talk we‚Äôll discuss how our tools affect our understanding, create a checklist of factors that make a component a component, and how to implement the theory of components with the tools you have at hand.

Presented by Elyse Holladay at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Linh Yao Pham: ‚ÄúDesign Systems for Data Products‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Themes and patterns in the design and application of systems for data products, analytic tools, and visualizations.

Presented by Linh Yao Pham at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Kaelig Deloumeau-Prigent
description: I held an AMA with Kaelig Deloumeau-Prigent over Zoom at 9am PDT April 28, 2020.

title: Abi Jones: ‚ÄúFor & Against Consistency‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Note: We were having A/V issues which unfortunately had sound playing during a part of Abi's talk. Please be kind. :)

‚Äî

One benefit of design systems is that they help ensure consistency across surfaces, platforms, and projects. The BBC claims that their design system, GEL enables them to ‚Äúcreate consistent and delightful user experiences‚Äù while Salesforce highlights consistency as one of their four design principles. But what does consistency mean in practice and when can it create conflict in a design system?

In this talk, we‚Äôll take a look at the differing types of consistency (internal, external, and real-world) and how they work in digital and physical interfaces, and we‚Äôll go a step further and dive into the myriad reasons that inconsistency can make sense, too. You‚Äôll walk away with a framework for making better trade-offs when deciding for or against consistency.

Presented by Abi Jones at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017.

title: Miriam Suzanne: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Use My Grid System‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Note: Miriam was filling in for Am√©lie Lamont who fell very ill and was unable to attend the conference. Miriam found out she was speaking less than 30 minutes before having to present.

---

I built Susy, a Sass grid system that can generate any grid technique you like ‚Äî but I haven't used it in years. I'll show you how various grid systems work, and how to avoid using them. For those few cases where a grid really is required, we'll talk about the best ways to roll your own, so you're not relying on a bloated library to make decisions for you. We'll also look at the new layout toys ‚Äî from flexbox to CSS Grid ‚Äî and how to get started with only a few lines of code.

- When to use floats, CSS Grid, flexbox, custom properties, and other techniques.
- How to make grid-math simple, and lose the grid-system.
- How to make grid-systems work for you when you need them.

Presented by Miriam Suzanne at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017. Ends with an interview with Una Kravets

title: Cameron Moll: ‚ÄúWhen We Align‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2017
description:
Disclaimers: one of the mics was left on near the emcee and organizer, so you can hear whispering/talking/ice clinking. Please forgive our error and be kind!

---

When we align, we seek positive outcomes for a system whose components may range from people to patterns, beliefs to behaviors, and much more. When we align, we arrive at a shared understanding of priorities, efficiencies, and tradeoffs. When we align, the result is purposeful and even beautiful.

In this keynote, Cameron will discuss three aspects of alignment within systems, not the least of which are design systems, and the remarkable outcomes that are made possible when we align.

Presented by Cameron Moll at Clarity 2017, on November 28th, 2017.

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Amy Hupe
description: I held an AMA with Amy Hupe over Zoom at 9am PDT April 24, 2020.

title: Richard Danne: ‚ÄúDesigning for Earthlings and Astronauts‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
Evolution of the NASA redesign with interesting details and anecdotes from the 1975 Program. Also the successful crowdfunding Reissue of our Design Manual in 2016.

Presented by Richard Danne at Clarity 2016, on April 1st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Maya Benari: ‚ÄúTurning the Ship: Living design systems in the federal government‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
The federal government, bound by centuries of history and numerous regulations, has historically built online experiences that reflect bureaucracy rather than human needs. Government websites that don't meet user needs produce poor outcomes and worse opinions about the government. We‚Äôre doing something about this. During the summer of 2015, a team came together to create the Draft US Web Design Standards: open source UI components and a visual style guide to create consistent, cohesive, and easy-to-use user experiences across federal government websites.

We‚Äôll explore:

- How to create a style guide in a highly complex, old system with multiple stakeholders and different end users
- How to make easy-to-use tools that solve real user needs
- How we're creating a nexus for industry best practices and collaboration across government agencies and with the public

Presented by Maya Benari at Clarity 2016, on April 1st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Chris Coyier
description: I held an AMA with Chris Coyier over Zoom at 9am PDT April 21, 2020.

title: Claudina Sarahe: ‚ÄúDeconstructing Web Systems; or, a Pattern Language for Web Develo‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
A pattern language is a method of describing good design practices within a field of expertise. This talk is an exercise to coalesce a pattern language for web development, in particular the discipline of front-end web design and development. It goes beyond the elements that comprise a design system or style guide focusing on the larger system of practices that contribute to delightful experiences for those that craft and code the experiences and interact with our web applications.

This talk is meant to spark a conversation. It is by no means a definite list of all the patterns, that can only be accomplished collectively.

Presented by Claudina Sarahe at Clarity 2016, on April 1st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Jeremy Perez-Cruz: ‚ÄúLiving Systems: Brand in the context of peoples lives‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
Some insight into the successes and failures of brand design and it‚Äôs relationship to being human.

Presented by Jeremy Perez-Cruz at Clarity 2016, on April 1st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Cordelia McGee-Tubb: ‚ÄúBaking Accessibility In‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
A quick web search can bring up thousands of code samples for any type of component one could imagine building, but 90% of that code isn‚Äôt accessible, unintentionally leaving huge audiences of users behind. You have the power to change this! As the people creating style guides and component systems, you‚Äôre uniquely positioned to get accessibility right the first time and spread best practices to everyone who uses your code. In this talk, you‚Äôll learn the key ingredients for baking accessibility into your design system, including mindful color palettes, semantic HTML, and a dash of ARIA. Let‚Äôs make the web better for everyone, one style guide at a time!

Presented by Cordelia McGee-Tubb at Clarity 2016, on April 1st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Val Head
description:
I held an AMA with Val Head over Zoom at 9am PDT April 17, 2020.

(Note: the connection was choppy so the video gets laggy ‚Äî¬†sorry!)

title: Rachel Nabors: ‚ÄúCommunicating Animation‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
Animation is key component of beautiful and useful product design. Salesforce, Google, and IBM all feature motion design in their design systems, and there‚Äôs every reason you should, too. When designers and developers agree upon constraints, they can create UI components faster and present a unified, polished look and feel users appreciate.

Communicating animation is all about identifying patterns and setting boundaries and behavior expectations. This means:

- creating custom easings that reinforce branding and physics
- choreographing scalable timing values
- creating a vocabulary of reusable components
- combining those components into unique yet universal animation patterns.

Whether your project is big or small, if it has a style guide, you will want to include motion design. In this talk, you will learn how to bring animation to heel.

Presented by Rachel Nabors at Clarity 2016, on April 1st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Stephanie Rewis & Brandon Ferrua: ‚ÄúCrawl, Walk, Run ‚Äì The Evolution of a Design Sys‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
If change isn‚Äôt built into the process, a ‚ÄúLiving Design System‚Äù can‚Äôt evolve. In this talk we'll discuss the lessons learned, and the challenges faced, as our system went from crawling to running. Refactoring, versioning, and deprecation are but a few of the growing pains we've experienced on our journey to build a stable but incredibly flexible Design System.

Presented by Stephanie Rewis & Brandon Ferrua at Clarity 2016, on March 31st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Miriam Suzanne: ‚ÄúCode Patterns for Pattern-Making‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
Style Guides and Pattern Libraries are great tools for documenting the relationships between code and design, but beautiful docs and consistent UI are only half the battle. Somewhere, behind the scenes, those patterns have to live in our code, and hopefully make life easier for developers. We can go beyond ‚Äúliving‚Äù style guides to find tools that encourage and document pattern-making from the ground up, across projects, without adding developer overhead. From Sass maps and Jinja macros, to front-end architecture and style-guide generators ‚Äî let‚Äôs talk about the code patterns that make our UI patterns possible.

Presented by Miriam Suzanne at Clarity 2016, on March 31st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Nathan Curtis: ‚ÄúBeyond the Toolkit: Spreading a System Across People & Products‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
A design system is made up of parts: visual style, UI components, code, editorial, and often more. We know how to design, build, deliver them is like any other digital product development process. And there‚Äôs the rub: your system is a product in and of itself, applied to an enterprise's ecosystem of other products built by autonomous teams of designers and developers.

Your strategy needs answers to ‚ÄúWhat products will use it, when and to what
extent?‚Äù ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs our audience?‚Äù ‚ÄúWho participates and contributes?‚Äù 
‚ÄúWhat groups must we align with?‚Äù ‚ÄúWho wants it, and ‚Äî really ‚Äî who doesn‚Äôt?‚Äù

We‚Äôll explore ways to identify and prioritize how to engage your enterprise‚Äôs people and products as you spread and sustain a system over time.

Presented by Nathan Curtis at Clarity 2016, on March 31st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Ask Me Anything with Design Systems Advocate, Jina Anne, featuring Nathan Curtis
description: I held an AMA with Nathan Curtis over Zoom at 9am PDT April 14, 2020.

title: Donna Chan & Isaak Hayes: ‚ÄúBuilding Empowering Style Guides with Practical Research‚Äù ‚Äî¬†Clarity 2016
description:
As builders and makers in tech, we strive to create useful, empowering products for our users. A style guide is no different. Done well, it‚Äôs a product that all of its users ‚Äî e.g. developers, designers, customers, partners, and more ‚Äî find useful and empowering to use. Where should a team start? It begins with understanding your users and the different things they need from style guides. Whether your team is small or large, we‚Äôll share practical research methods for gathering and translating these different needs into building useful and empowering style guides.

Presented by Donna Chan & Isaak Hayes at Clarity 2016, on March 31st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Brad Frost: ‚ÄúThe Thing is Design Systems. The Time is Now.‚Äù ‚Äî Clarity 2016
description:
Modularity has been around for a long time now; concepts like object-oriented programming predate the Web by a long shot. So why the sudden interest in pattern libraries and design systems on the Web? We‚Äôre tasked with creating experiences that look and function beautifully across a dizzying array of devices, browsers, screen sizes, network connections, locales, and environments. That‚Äôs a tall order in and of itself, but once you factor in team members, clients, stakeholders, and organizational quirks, things start looking downright intimidating. Style guides and design systems provide solid ground for us to stand on as we tackle this increasingly-diverse Web landscape. This session will discuss considerations and best practices for creating and maintaining effective interface design systems.

Presented by Brad Frost at Clarity 2016, on March 31st, 2016. Ends with an interview with Chris Coyier

title: Accessibility and inclusivity in Design Systems (DSCC Toronto)
description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Toronto
at Wealthsimple Toronto
on March 4, 2020

--
0:00 Introduction
7:35 Talk #1: The building blocks of an accessible design system by George Zamfir
33:21 Talk #1: Questions and Answers
42:55 Talk #2: International is inclusive by Winter Wei
1:08:55 Talk #2: Questions and Answers
1:15:15 Outro
--

Talk #1: The building blocks of an accessible design system
George Zamfir, Accessibility Product Manager @Slack

What does it take to build an accessible product? Among other things, an accessible design system! I‚Äôll talk about Slack Kit, Slack‚Äôs design system, and a selection of the building blocks that made it possible and accessible. Today Slack Kit powers product development at Slack but that was not always the case, this is the story of how we got here.

About George
George builds digital products for the variety of human abilities. He's done so with Scotiabank, Facebook, TELUS Digital, design agencies, government and most recently with Slack. He's passionate about helping people build accessible products / programs / teams / culture!

--
Talk #2: International is inclusive
Winter Wei, UX Manager of Localization @Shopify

Do you remember the last time you tried to use a website or product that‚Äôs not in your language, an app or a payment method that wouldn‚Äôt work in a different country? Do you remember how frustrating that was? The world is literally becoming a village. Considering people from different cultures, speaking different languages, having different preferences and limitations is as important as considering accessibility and anti-discrimination when it comes to inclusive design. In this talk we will cover what internationalization and localization mean for a product company, the consequences of not doing it properly, why design system is the natural place to start this work, how we approach it at Shopify, and the lessons we‚Äôve learnt so far.

About Winter
Winter is the UX Manager of Localization at Shopify, leading the internationalization and localization of Shopify foundations while enabling every teams to build for international markets. Previously she grew and led the design team at Kira Systems where she specialized in designing for AI-human interaction and information retrieval. Some of her research and design work are published in reputable academic venues. She‚Äôs an aspiring cellist, knowing that she may never be Yo-Yo Ma but keeps on trying anyway.

--
About Design Systems Community
Design Systems Community helps bring people together to share ways of working, successes, and other learnings to encourage best practices in building, scaling, and maintaining design systems. No matter how you engage with design systems, we all play a role in making information accessible for everyone, and without barriers.

description:
Hosted by Design Systems Community Chapter Toronto
at Rangle.io Toronto
on February 5, 2020

--
5:15 Introduction
11:39 Talk #1: Design Systems on a Rocket Ship by Diogo Ramos
37:22 Talk #1: Questions and Answers
46:00 Talk #2: Launching a Lean Design System by Jake Janosik and Mostafa Elhefnawy
1:18:54 Talk #2: Questions and Answers
1:26:15 Outro + a Joke
--

Talk #1: Design Systems on a Rocket Ship
Diogo Ramos, Senior Product Designer, League

So everyone at your company understands the value of a design system and you think you got buy-in to build one. But did you? For small, fast-moving teams, this kind of initiative can, at times, be seen as too much of an effort and cost. Resources that are being spent on design systems aren‚Äôt being spent on building features for the product. So how can your company have their cake and eat it too? This talk will explore strategies that will help you get support and grow a design system when challenges arise.

About Diogo
Diogo is a product designer living and working in Toronto. He is currently a Senior Product Designer at League on a mission to help people live better, healthier lives through thoughtful design. He‚Äôs also spearheading League‚Äôs design system, Genesis. Outside of design Diogo drinks a lot of coffee and plays a lot of soccer, but he also loves architecture, dogs, movies and music. He lived in 4 different countries and his favorite animal is an Otter.

--
Talk #2: Launching a Lean Design System
Jake Janosik, Manager Product Design, Snaptravel
Mostafa Elhefnawy, Sr. Product Manager, Snaptravel

What happens when you work for a small startup and your design system needs to launch while making new features and not holding up growth? We will explore how we approached building a lean and mean design system, what we learned during build and launch, and where we are today because of it.

About Jake
Jake is a product designer from Toronto, currently leading and managing the design team at Snaptravel, where he owned the creation of their design system, Atlas. He previously worked at several agencies in Toronto, advising and designing for startups and working inside enterprise companies making impactful products. Outside of work, you can find him in a coffee shop daydreaming, attending loud concerts or hiking around the world.

About Mostafa
Mostafa has been in product throughout his whole career both as an individual contributing product manager and as someone that built out and managed a product team. He‚Äôs worked on a range of different types of products/businesses such as SaaS, Marketplaces, E-commerce, Native Apps, Web, and Chatbots. Throughout each of his roles, he‚Äôs had a very close relationship with the Design team which gave him first-hand exposure to some of the problems that a product and design team faces in the absence of a design system

She's particularly obsessed with Design Systems, Design Operations and creating consistent, effective brand experiences across multiple devices & platforms. She also uses her fondness of planning and systems into her love of quilting during her spare time.

Talk #2: Scaling Design Systems, inclusively
Eduardo Alarcon, Director, Global Digital Design Systems, Scotiabank

Canvas, Scotiabank‚Äôs Global Design System, is turning 3 years old and it‚Äôs now being used in more than 5 countries. How are we scaling it in an inclusive way? Let‚Äôs talk about the framework we‚Äôre using to design winning strategies, and some of the lessons we‚Äôve learned along the way

His purpose is to help transform the world into a happier place for everyone, and that‚Äôs why he‚Äôs passionate about unlocking the exponential power Design Systems have, to enable organizations in building world-class digital experiences that everyone loves. Eduardo moved from Peru early this year and is constantly playing with local ingredients to continue learning how to cook delicious Peruvian food that also brings joyful moments to the table.

title: Making Design System a Success - Create a Design System in Sketch, Ep9
description:
Episode 9: Making Design System a Success

In this episode for creating fully functional atomic design systems from scratch, I'll talk about 2 vital parts making this effort a success. Too often efforts that are done in isolation and that lack necessary buy-ins tend to end up collecting dust. What was meant to be transformative new living product design system becomes a crutch? This video will help you understand how to set up the right structures for people and underlying process so that you can start a system, but also ensure it will become an integral part of new feature design and development. 

A design system is a collection of reusable product design components, that are guided by clear standards. Design system patterns are usually tested with end-users, thus can be easily assembled into new features. If properly set up, experimented, tested and maintained a well-defined system is one of the best designer‚Äôs friends. Furthermore, a living design system is one of the most important step-ups for mature designops and UX design organizations. This mini-series will cover exactly that: how to make a simple design system from scratch using Sketch and Atomic design principles.

description:
Episode 8: Design Systems: Getting Business Buy-in 

In this video, I'll discuss the biggest issue that designers and engineers alike face when trying to introduce the very first atomic design system -- getting the buy-in from the business. Some designers don't even know where to start, others continuously struggle to convey design system value. There is one simple (not easy) workaround to conveying the value the businesses seek immediately. And it doesn't matter if you are using Sketch or Figma or what sort of organisation you're part of. If this is your first initiative with design systems - check the video. These principles will work for almost any design based initiative.

A design system is a collection of reusable product design components, that are guided by clear standards. title: Developer Handovers with Zeplin - Create a Design System in Sketch, Ep7
description:
Episode 7: Developer Handovers with Zeplin

If you're a Sketch user and have been following along this design system tutorial series you probably have already noticed the gradual transition from the smallest atoms to pages that need to be somehow implemented. Too often expectations and design details get lost in the weeds because of the lack of a common environment to retain all the UI patterns. In this video on design systems, I'll share some of the easiest ways to perform design asset handovers to your front-end developers - Zeplin. 

A design system is a collection of reusable product design components, that are guided by clear standards. Design system patterns are usually tested with end-users, thus can be easily assembled into new features. If properly set up, experimented, tested and maintained a well-defined system is one of the best designer‚Äôs friends. Furthermore, a living design system is one of the most important step-ups for mature designops and UX design organisations. This mini-series will cover exactly that: how to make a simple design system from scratch using Sketch and Atomic design principles.

title: Mix'n'match UI Patterns Into Organisms - Create a Design System in Sketch, Ep5
description:
Episode 5: Mix'n'match UI Patterns Into Organisms

In this video, we will continue crafting atoms, molecules and the new construct in the Atomic Design system hierarchy - Organisms. We will combine previously covered atom and molecule patterns into intuitive and easy to maintain  a set of patterns.

A design system is a collection of reusable product design components, that are guided by clear standards. Design system patterns are usually tested with end-users, thus can be easily assembled into new features. If properly set up, experimented, tested and maintained a well-defined system is one of the best designer‚Äôs friends. Furthermore, a living design system is one of the most important step-ups for mature designops and UX design organisations. This mini-series will cover exactly that: how to make a simple design system from scratch using Sketch and Atomic design principles.

title: Design Systems: What are They and How to Get Started
description:
If you're thinking to scale a UX team, assure consistency across the range of products, or need a better all-round collaboration enhancement -- design systems are an invaluable asset. It can save tremendous amounts of time, allow for easy handovers to development, as well as keep the brand new feature development smooth. In this video I'll walk you through some examples of great design systems, show you how to get started and 2 key strategies to make it successful.

‚öíÔ∏èTools to get started: 
Invision Design System Manager (DSM): https://www.invisionapp.com/design-system-manager/
Figma: https://www.figma.com/
Zeplin: https://zeplin.io/

üîÑSystem examples:
Gov.uk design system: https://design-system.service.gov.uk/
Google's material design system: https://material.io/design/
Lego design system: bricks!
